And I remember one
time-- and again, I

2596.88.text: didn't put it in the book.

2598.59.text:
Our team, it was a minor league
affiliate of the Yankees.

2602.61.text:
I don't know, we
lost 16 to nothing.

2604.11.text:
And he'd always go
into the clubhouse

2605.65.text: after the end of each game.

2607.84.text: And he would say, great game.

2611.58.text:
And the coach would
say, how could you

2613.16.text: say we had a great game?

2614.59.text:
He'd say, Oh,
everybody tried hard.

2616.43.text:
Everybody did the
best they could.

2618.62.text: That was the kind of guy he was.

2619.95.text:
So when you hang around
that all your life,

2624.99.text:
Hang around people that
are positive influences.

2628.91.text:
Stay close to people who
can be helpful to you,

2631.97.text:
and not drag you
down, but pick you up.

2638.38.text:
And I think that's
where I got mine from.

2643.05.text:
AUDIENCE: So it sounds like it's
almost kind of this tendency

2645.70.text:
to resilience, which
maybe you cultivated just

2648.30.text:
from seeing your dad,
and going through that.

2651.07.text:
JOE PLUMERI: Yeah,
and again, I think

2654.80.text: you are a product of something.

2657.97.text:
And I was a product
of what I saw.

2661.68.text:
And I was lucky
enough-- I could have

2667.45.text:
But I had the privilege,
and the good fortune

2671.55.text:
of seeing somebody that
had a positive influence.

2673.84.text: The guy just wouldn't give up.

2676.45.text:
He just kept bouncing
back up again.

2679.31.text:
JOE PLUMERI: Yeah, and so that's
why I think it's important.

2684.22.text:
And you'll see, cut a path is
the principle in the book which

2691.05.text:
talks about my father
and my grandfather,

2693.07.text:
and the legacy in my family
of always cutting a path.

2697.88.text:
There's choices
you have in life.

2699.49.text:
I gave you one of them, pain
of discipline, pain of regret.

2701.99.text:
The other one is, cut a
path and leave a trail.

2705.99.text:
Or let somebody else cut the
path, and you follow them.

2710.26.text:
In business, first
to the market wins.

2714.26.text:
In life, I think you
just go cut a path,

2717.26.text:
and then wait for everybody
else to want to follow you.

2720.39.text:
They're not the ones
that are the winners.

2723.05.text:
This place is a great
example of that.

2726.18.text:
So he was always a person that
cut a path, and left a trail.

2730.39.text:
And I've always
been the same way.

2732.68.text:
And in business, it's called
be the first to the market,

2739.82.text:
If you have a customer, you
don't sell them, you help them.

2742.61.text:
It's subtle things
like that make

2744.74.text:
you feel and want people to do
better, and they're positive.

2748.95.text:
AUDIENCE: So my question
is, you mentioned

2751.16.text:
that you kind of regret
not having spent more time

2754.39.text: with your son before he passed.

2755.93.text:
After he did pass
away, did you see

2758.66.text:
a change in kind of
the amount of time

2760.91.text:
you spent with either
family, or time you took off,

2763.47.text:
or in terms of how
much you worked

2767.07.text: as a learning out of that?

2768.59.text:
And then what kind of things you
recommend for people these days

2772.93.text: JOE PLUMERI: The answer is yes.

2775.57.text:
And frankly, when I was
on a plane last night,

2780.61.text:
He had a daughter, who's now 13,
who my ex-wife and I adopted.

2790.20.text:
And so I'm the father,
and the grandfather.

2793.97.text:
And I worry that I don't
spend enough time with her.

2797.89.text:
I mentioned that to
my wife last night.

2799.51.text:
I said, I gotta spend
more time with Elizabeth.

2804.34.text:
I don't know that I could
even ask that question

2809.28.text: I wouldn't have even asked it.

2812.57.text:
I think I'm pretty close
to my other children,

2815.66.text: but I get paranoid that I'm not.

2818.86.text:
Because when you go through
something like that,

2823.66.text: doing the right thing or not.

2825.68.text:
Whether you said the
right thing or not.

2830.09.text:
I think it's healthy that
I constantly question,

2835.57.text:
Or I constantly question,
am I spending enough time

2841.51.text:
All because of the
experience that I had.

2843.51.text:
And as long as I keep
questioning myself,

2849.41.text:
So my recommendation
would be, don't

2852.86.text: go through what I went through.

2855.20.text:
But keep questioning everything
that you do personally

2858.93.text:
with your friends,
or with your family.

2860.68.text:
And question whether
or not the relationship

2863.55.text:
is as tight as it should be, and
as heartfelt as it should be.

2867.76.text:
AUDIENCE: Just really
quickly, on the subject

2870.99.text:
How do you balance questioning
yourself versus confidence?

2874.67.text:
JOE PLUMERI: Questioning
yourself versus confidence?

2882.15.text:
Everybody always says,
that guy's got swagger.

2885.59.text:
And there's something
cool about swagger.

2889.18.text:
And so I always try to
think about what swagger

2892.80.text: would be if you defined it.

2894.99.text: And this is what swagger is.

2898.34.text:
North of confident,
and south of arrogant.

2907.26.text:
You want to be around
confident people,

2909.53.text:
but you don't want to be around
people that are arrogant.

2912.95.text:
You want to be around,
this is a confident person

2915.61.text:
who has a sense of class, style,
and has respect for people.

2920.51.text:
And so you want to stay south
of arrogant, north of confident,

2923.72.text:
and that land right there
is where you want to be.

2929.88.text:
And always keep
asking yourself, did I

2934.22.text:
Or did I go above the
line of arrogance?

2938.66.text:
North of confident,
south of arrogant

2941.12.text:
is the swagger you want
to have every day, when

2947.62.text:
I want to really thank
you guys for coming today.

2950.11.text: It's really been a lot of fun.

2951.99.text:
I appreciate you giving me the
opportunity to talk to you,

2954.28.text: and spend the time with you.
